Fig. 1 Single crystal X-ray structure for 1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Substrate scope with 2-fluoroaniline derivative. All the reactions were performed with 0.064 mmol of catalyst 2, 0.64 mmol of substrate 3, 0.97 mmol of substrate 4 at 100 °C and their isolated yield is mentioned below. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Substrate scope with benzylamine derivative. All the reactions were performed with 1.39 mmol of 6, 0.93 mmol of 7 and 0.093 mmol of catalyst 2 in DMF at 100 °C. Isolated yield with fluro derivatives. The yield given in parentheses is with bromo derivatives. Fig. 3 Scheme 1 Synthetic approaches for the benzothiazole scaffolds. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Synthesis of binuclear double-stranded helicates (1) [Eu2(H2L)2Cl2(H2O)2]Cl4(H2O)4 and (2) [Tb2(H2L)2(H2O)6]Cl6(H2O)5. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Control experiments. The ratio of the thiourea and benzothiazole molecules is determined by the LCMS analysis of the crude samples. The isolated yields are given for (ii, iii). Scheme 3 Scheme 4 Probable mechanism. Scheme 4 Scheme 5 Synthesis of Riluzole. Scheme 5 Scheme 6 Synthesis of Dimazole. Scheme 6 Table 1 Screening of the catalysts. a . Table 1 Image 1 Entry Catalyst Yield b (%) 1 1 (5 mol%) 45 2 1 (10 mol%) 80 3 1 (20 mol%) 83 4 2 (5 mol%) 55 5 2 (10 mol%) 85 6 2 (20 mol%) 83 7 c K2CO3 10 8 d Blank 9 a All the reactions were performed with 0.64 mmol of 3, 0.97 mmol of 4 and 0.032–0.128 mmol of catalyst loading in DMF at 100 °C, 16 h. b Isolated yield. c Reaction in the presence of only base and absence of a catalyst. d Reaction in the presence of only base and absence of a catalyst. Table 2 Optimization of reaction condition. a Table 2 Image 2 Entry Solvent Additive Temp.(°C) Yield (%) b, c 1 DMSO --- 100 5 2 2-Butanol --- 100 60 3 Ethyl acetate --- 100 30 4 EMK --- 100 60 5 Water --- 100 n.d. 6 DMF TBAB 100 78 7 DMF K2CO3 100 60 8 DMF --- 80 70 9 DMF --- 100 85 10 DMF --- 120 78 11 DMF --- 100 85 a All the reactions were performed with 0.064 mmol of catalyst 2, 0.64 mmol of substrate 3, 0.97 mmol of substrate 4 at 100 °C. b Isolated yield c 0.1 equiv. Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Division, CSIR-Central Salt and Marine Chemicals Research Institute Bhavnagar Gujarat 364002 India ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Geometrically unsaturated binuclear double-stranded metallohelicates constructed with pyridyl hydrazine ligands and lanthanide metal ions via metal-templated self-assembly. The single-crystal X-ray analysis suggests the formation of helical assembly through its coordination with pyridyl, azomethine nitrogen’s and ketonic oxygen with metal ions. Lanthanide ions are known to possess multiple coordination sites, other labile sites are occupied with solvents and anions. The lanthanide helicates are exhaustively characterized and adopted as a catalyst to synthesize benzothiazole scaffolds starting from 2-fluoroaniline and phenyl isothiocyanate substrates via tandem thiourea intermediate/cyclization pathway. The mechanistic investigation suggests the reaction proceeds via the nucleophilic aromatic substitution pathway. The protocols are extended for the synthesis of drug molecules such as Riluzole and Dimazole. Graphical Abstract The binuclear double-stranded terbium helicates are adopted as efficient catalyst for the synthesis of heterocyclic benzothiazole scaffolds. Keywords Lanthanide helicates Benzothiazoles Reaction Thiourea intermediate Drug molecules Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Metal-templated self-assembly is a unique technique to achieve complex supramolecular architectures [1–3]. Among the metallosupramolecular assemblies, the metallohelicates are well known for their structural significance, helical chirality and chiroptical properties etc [4–7]. The subtle change in self-assembly reaction parameters leads to molecules with inspiring chemistry and excellent functional applications in biomedical [8–10], sensors [11,12] and catalysis [13–16]. Lanthanide helicates are rarely exploited in catalysis but their multiple coordination sites and Lewis's acidic nature are known to deliver excellent catalysis with well-designed ligands [17–20]. Benzothiazoles are the inspiring heteroaromatic scaffolds that have potential core motifs in synthesizing various bio-inspired molecules [21–27]. Earlier, the benzothiazoles were achieved via two steps (i) ortho–halo thiourea intermediate synthesis followed by (ii) cyclization of intermediate in the presence of catalytic Pd or Cu [28–32]. The protocol has been documented by the condensation of 2-aminothiophenol with aldehyde, ketone, etc., in the presence of a suitable catalyst/promotor ( Scheme 1a) [33–35]. Follow-up, the one-pot synthesis of benzothiazoles starting from 2-haloaniline with phenyl isothiocyanate via the in-situ thiourea intermediate formation is reported with catalyst and base additive. The in-situ generated Cu and Fe complexes with suitable ligands are explored for this conversion and the base or phase transfer catalysts are required for the formation of thiourea intermediate (Scheme 1b) [36–44]. The in-situ generated Cu-glycosyltriazole catalyst enables the synthesis of benz-fused azoles via intramolecular cross-coupling. In such reaction usage of potassium carbonate is essential for intermediate formation and the reaction required 120 °C in DMF [45]. Similarly, a porous aromatic framework constructed with phenanthroline is used as a heterogeneous catalyst for benzothiazole synthesis in the presence of NaHCO3 at 80 °C in an aqueous medium [46]. Most of the reported protocols require base additives or a long reaction time. Herein we have adopted the synthesis of binuclear double-stranded helicates with inner transition metal ions Eu3+ and Tb3+. These helicates are adopted as a catalyst for the synthesis of heterocyclic benzothiazole scaffolds (Scheme 1c). The catalyst is found efficient for aniline and benzylamine substrates under additive-free conditions and the protocols have extended to the synthesis of Riluzole and Dimazole drugs. 2 Results and Discussiondiscussion The multidentate ligand H2 L and its binuclear double-stranded helicates are synthesized following our recent report ( Scheme 2) [47–49]. Treating the ligand with lanthanide salts in a 1:1 ratio leads to the formation of coordination-driven binuclear helicate assembly. The structural analysis of these molecules is established by single-crystal X-ray techniques. These europium and terbium helicates are demonstrated already for their selective sensing property towards the detection of bio-phosphates (AMP) in an aqueous medium [50]. The suitable crystals for the 1 are obtained by slow diffusion of acetonitrile solution into the water. The structural analysis confirms the formation of binuclear double-stranded helicate assemblies ( Fig. 1). The metal ions in the complex exist in a +3 oxidation state with the coordination number 9. The six metal sites are coordinated with ligand molecules via NNO chelates of each ligand and the remaining three sites are occupied with labile anion and solvent molecules on each europium metal center. The helicate molecules are discrete ionic and crystallized in the orthorhombic system, Aba2 space group (Supporting Information, Table S2). Each metal site is occupied by one chloride ion and two water molecules and the metal ions are separated by a distance of 7.754 Å. The helical twist is reflected at the -CH2-CH2- spacer which links both the pyridyl acylhydrazone coordinating moieties (Fig. 1). The crystal analysis of 2 exhibits a similar structural pattern as described in our earlier report [50]. The metallohelicate 1 and 2 exhibits red and green luminescence in their solid and solution state. 2.1 Catalyst screening Followed by the structural establishment, the lanthanide helicates (1-2) are adopted as a catalyst for the synthesis of benzothiazole scaffolds. The aniline (3) and phenyl isothiocyanate (4) derivatives are chosen as model substrates for catalyst screening ( Table 1). The substrate with electron-withdrawing functionalities is found efficient under additive-free conditions. The reactions are performed in the presence of 5 mol% catalysts in DMF medium at 100 °C in the absence of additive and monitored. The benzothiazole (5) is isolated in 45% and 55% in the presence of catalysts 1 and 2 respectively (Table 1; Entry 1&4). In the presence of only potassium carbonate, a 10% yield was obtained whereas in the blank reaction, the expected product was formed in trace amounts (Table 1; Entry 7&8). In the presence of a 10 mol% catalyst, the yield increased to 80% with catalyst 1 and 85% with catalyst 2 (Table 1; Entry 2&5) whereas with 20 mol% catalyst doesn’t give a significant increase in yield (Table 1; Entry 3&6). Hence the presence of 2 (10 mol%) as a catalyst is found efficient and continued for the optimization. 2.2 Optimization of reaction condition The optimization of the reaction condition by screening solvent, additive and temperature with catalyst 2 was attempted ( Table 2). The reaction with DMSO or water does not yield the desired product (Table 2, Entry 1,5). In the presence of ethyl acetate medium, 30% and with 2-butanol or EMK, 60% of the desired product is isolated (Table 2, Entry 2–4). The DMF is chosen as a suitable solvent based on the yield. In the reaction with TBAB as a phase transfer catalyst in DMF at 100 °C, 78% of the desired product is isolated (Table 2; Entry 6). Similarly adapting potassium carbonate as a base additive, 60% of the benzothiazole (5) is obtained (Table 2; Entry 7). Upon varying temperature from 80 to 120 °C (Table 2; Entry 8–11), the 100 °C is found efficient with 85% of the isolated yield (Table 2; Entry 11). 2.3 Substrate scope The scope of the substrates was extended under optimized reaction conditions with 10 mol% catalyst 2 in DMF medium at 100 °C ( Fig. 2). The protocol is well tolerated with amine derivatives having electron-withdrawing groups such as acid, ester, nitro, cyano with diverse phenyl isothiocyanate substrates (Supporting Information S4, S8). The novel benzothiazole scaffolds are obtained with better yield (Fig. 2, 5a-5ad). The nitro-substituted anilines yielded benzothiazoles with more than 80% yield, due to their strong electron-withdrawing nature. However, the results are not encouraging with the unsubstituted amine and phenyl isothiocyanate derivatives which failed to yield the desired product. In addition, the reaction doesn’t proceed with leaving a group other than fluoride. Following these results, alternatively, we performed the reactions of benzylamine (7) with halogen-substituted phenyl isothiocyanates (6) using our catalysts and the results are depicted in Fig. 3 (Supporting Information S4, S8). Interestingly the catalyst is giving better conversion even with unsubstituted substrates such as benzylamine, aliphatic, α-methyl amines, etc. Similarly, the phenyl isothiocyanates with different halides at the ortho position yielded the desired product but the fluro and bromo substrates are better. In comparison, the 2-bromophenyl isothiocyanates give better conversion than fluro derivatives (Fig. 3). The benzothiazole scaffolds with benzylamine were obtained in 62% (8a) whereas in the case of 4-methoxy, 4-trifluoromethylbenzylamine, 65% and 66% of yield were obtained (Fig. 3, 8b, b’). The protocol tolerates aliphatic amines such as dimethyl amine and butyl amine with a 70% yield of the desired benzothiazoles (Fig. 3, 8c, 8d). The reactions with 1-Phenylethylamine (Fig. 3, 8e) and 4-(Trifluoromethyl)phenyl isothiocyanate (Fig. 3, 8 f) produce 73% benzothiazole molecules in the presence of catalyst 2. 2.4 Mechanistic investigation In order to understand the path of the reactions, control experiments were performed. The literature report suggests that the conversion proceeds via the thiourea intermediate (Supporting Information S5, S8). The temperature has a significant impact on the tandem reaction in the presence of Tb catalyst 2. In the absence of a catalyst, the conversion is not determined at room temperature, whereas at 100 °C the trace formation of benzothiazole is observed ( Scheme 3, i). In the presence of a 10 mol% catalyst at room temperature, the thiourea intermediate is obtained with substrates with or without electron-withdrawing functionalities. The respective thiourea intermediate is isolated in yield ranging from 45% to 65% respectively (Scheme 3, ii, iii). When the reaction temperature is raised to 100 °C, the crude analysis suggests the formation of 28% thiourea intermediate and 58% of benzothiazole in 5 h (Scheme 3, iv). Hence the temperature has a significant role in the tandem reaction to obtain the benzothiazole scaffolds. The reaction performed with radical scavenger (TEMPO, 1 equivalent), the benzothiazole has not formed suggesting the reaction proceeds via a radical pathway (Scheme 3, v). The reaction performed at room temperature leads to the selective formation of thiourea derivative. The control experiments suggest the reaction proceeds via the thiourea intermediate followed by the intramolecular cyclization leads to the benzothiazole scaffolds (Scheme 3). 2.5 Proposed mechanism Based on the catalytic protocol and control experiments, a possible mechanism is proposed Scheme 4. The literature reports [46,51–55] on transition metal catalysts follow a cross-coupling pathway whereas the Tb helicate (2), proceeds via the nucleophilic aromatic substitution pathway. In the presence of an electron-withdrawing group at the para position, the electronegativity increases and favors sulfur attack which accelerates the reaction under additive-free conditions. Fluoride is found to be the best leaving group due to its high electronegativity. The reaction of 2-fluoroaniline with phenyl isothiocyanates undergoes thiourea formation at room temperature. The substrate can chelate with the metal center via the amine group by water elimination (a). The presence of labile -NH in the ligands enhances the nucleophilic addition of fluoroaniline with phenyl isothiocyanate leading to the formation of a thiourea intermediate (c). The nucleophilicity of the nitrogen weakens the C-F bond which facilitates the sulfur attack (d) which leads to the cyclization of the thiourea intermediate following the radical pathway (e). The aromatic rearrangement leads to the desired benzothiazole molecules with HF elimination. As suggested in the literature, the DMF solvent also enhances cyclization[56]. 2.6 Synthetic applications The catalytic application of helicate 2 was extended towards the synthesis of potential drug molecules such as Riluzole (Supporting Information S6) and Dimazole (Supporting Information S7). The drug Riluzole [57,58] was obtained via the two-step synthesis ( Scheme 5). The first step involves the coupling of 4-methoxybenzylamine (9) and phenyl isothiocyanate derivative (10) providing the benzothiazole scaffold (11) with 84% isolated yield under optimized conditions. The second step involves the debenzylation of benzothiazole with ceric ammonium nitrate (CAN) at room temperature leading to the Riluzole molecules (12) with a 90% yield. Similarly, the dimazole was attempted ( Scheme 6) by reaction of phenyl isothiocyanate substrate (13) with dimethylamine. The optimized reaction condition with 10 mol% of catalyst 2 yielded 87% of the benzothiazole molecule (14). Followed by the alkylation of the hydroxyl group with amine substrate 15 which produces 79% of the dimazole molecules (16). 3 Conclusion The binuclear double-stranded metallohelicates are synthesized by treating pyridyl hydrazine ligands with lanthanide metal ions. The lanthanide complexes are well characterized and the structures are established by single-crystal X-ray techniques. The ligands wrapped around the metal center in a helical fashion and the vacant sites are occupied with chloride and water molecules. The metallohelicates are adopted as suitable catalysts for the synthesis of benzothiazole from 2-fluoroaniline and isothiocyanates via tandem thiourea intermediate. The broad substrate scope, the role of temperature and electron-withdrawing functionalities are well established with appropriate control experiments. The Tb helicate (2) is specific towards the 2-fluoroaniline substrates with the electron-withdrawing group in the para position. The protocol is extended towards the synthesis of drug molecules such as Riluzole and Dimazole. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General methods 4.1.1 Materials and general methods All reactions were carried out with oven-dried glassware under aerobic conditions. The reactions were carried out in commercial solvents without drying or degassing. All the anilines and the bases were commercially available and were used as received without further purification. Aryl isothiocyanates were prepared according to the procedures available in the literature. LC-MS data were recorded on an Agilent Technologies 1200 LC system coupled with Agilent Technologies 5975 C mass spectrometer using HP-column (4.6 mm×50 mm, 5μ). 1H and 13C NMR spectra were obtained in CDCl3 or DMSO-d6 using 300 MHz or 400 MHz Bruker NMR spectrometer. All the chemical shift values reported in the 1H NMR spectra are in parts per million (ppm) on the δ scale from an internal standard of residual CDCl3 (7.26 ppm) or the central peak of DMSO-d6 (2.50 ppm). Single crystal structures were determined using a BRUKER SMART APEX (CCD) diffractometer. The compounds were purified by flash chromatography using Biotage Selekt auto column on a pre-packed 25-gram KP-Sil BiotageƟ SNAP. Melting points were measured with a Polmon AUTO-MELT MP98 apparatus. 4.2 Synthesis of benzothiazoles To a solution of 2-fluoroaniline (0.64 mmol) in DMF, isothiocyanate (0.97 mmol) and catalyst (0.064 mmol) were added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 100 ℃ for 16 h. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. Upon completion of the reaction, the reaction mass was diluted with water and extracted using ethyl acetate. The combined ethyl acetate layers were once again washed with water, brine and dried over anhydrous sodium sulphate and concentrated under reduced pressure at 45 °C. The crude product was purified by a flash column and characterized. CRediT authorship contribution statement Palani S Subramanian: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: Geometrically unsaturated binuclear double-stranded metallohelicates constructed with pyridyl hydrazine ligands and lanthanide metal ions via metal-templated self-assembly. The single-crystal X-ray analysis suggests the formation of helical assembly through its coordination with pyridyl, azomethine nitrogen’s and ketonic oxygen with metal ions. Lanthanide ions are known to possess multiple coordination sites, other labile sites are occupied with solvents and anions. The lanthanide helicates are exhaustively characterized and adopted as a catalyst to synthesize benzothiazole scaffolds starting from 2-fluoroaniline and phenyl isothiocyanate substrates via tandem thiourea intermediate/cyclization pathway. The mechanistic investigation suggests the reaction proceeds via the nucleophilic aromatic substitution pathway. The protocols are extended for the synthesis of drug molecules such as Riluzole and Dimazole.
coredata.prism:publisher: Elsevier B.V. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.
coredata.dc:title: Self-Assembled Lanthanide Supramolecular Helicates: Efficient Catalysts for Synthesis of Heterocyclic Scaffolds
